title: Between 30 April 2021 and 31 December 2021, how many times will the Council of the European Union impose new restrictive measures (sanctions) on China over human rights violations and abuses in Xinjiang?
preds: EU has other things on its mind.
The EU wants to show itself as a protector of Human rights. It is likely it will continue to sanction china.

Since repressions in Xinjiang entered an acute phase in 2017, the EU has imposed sanctions on Chinese officials over human rights violations and abuses in Xinjiang once.  One month is left in this prediction; since January 2017, the EU has imposed sanctions in 1/59 months.  EU officials have said there will be no new sanctions given the situation in Xinjiang has not materially changed.

Precious sanctions were renewed. 
https://www.scmp.com/news/china/diplomacy/article/3157250/eu-set-renew-sanctions-chinese-officials-alleged-xinjiang?module=live&pgtype=homepage PengShuai
New German coalition documents indicate stronger stance vs China
Olympics2022
Moving to 0% given that the EU recently had to beg China to increase magnesium production. China has leverage.
Time is running out on this challenge and forging an agreement with China on climate change is the more burning issue.  It seems highly unlikely that the EU will want to complicate that issue.

Although 40 UN member states recently voiced human rights  concern for the  Uyghurs In Xinjiang  the prediction holds since it is not the economic  interests of China or the EU  to be engaged in a political sword fight.
Still think it's unlikely because it had been unprecedented for much of history. However, China has vowed to take back Taiwan this week. However, the question is limited to Xinjiang.
The fact that there were sanctions in March reduce the chances of a new round, minus an event.
Always a chance China could do something.. but very low
EU and France will want to be relevant to the South Pacific region.
The EC's new report on a ban of Chinese forced labour products increases the likelihood that new restrictive measures on China will be placed.
I think that the recent Uyghur tribunal ending in London may influence some action this week, however the overall chances are still low.

Based on the European Commissions press releases, it seems like for the near future theya re more focused on COVID and Afghanistan as opposed to China and Xinjiang.  I think that it is very unlikely that they would put measures on Xinjiang at this time.

All in. 
The cowards have spoken.

The EU is in a tough place.  They want to say something, but can they economically?  The dependence on China for exports and imports mean it’s hard to risk that because voters, while wanting to find some way to make comment on what happens in China, actually respond more immediately to economic impetus.  This means any disruption in business is seem and felt much more strongly than e more hidden ethical concerns in supply chains.  We’ve all seen this for years. Plus as Germany (sorry France, yes you’re big too, but despite all efforts, are still not there) is the main player in the EU, but is heavily dependent on China and has elections coming up, I can’t see where the driver for condemning China more than has happened comes from this year. It’s still possible, but unlikely.

This forecast is based on: 1-The rising & continous tension bet E.U& PRC in the field of sanctions passed Xingjiang& stopped few months ago with no further actions against Hongkong violence. 2- The sanction will be on Taiwan (the coming event in 2022) and that is why The Chinese gov prepare this law:
https://www.china-briefing.com/news/chinas-anti-foreign-sanctions-law-how-businesses-should-prepare/ Further investigation: 
1-US approves potential $750 million weapons sales to Taiwan
August 6, 2021 (Mainichi Japan
https://mainichi.jp/english/articles/20210805/p2g/00m/0in/035000c 2-Is Taiwan next?
https://www.nytimes.com/2021/08/04/magazine/taiwan-china.html

An additional issue with the EU as compared with countries like the UK, US, and Canada, is that such sanctions need to be unanimously approved by all 27 member states (https://www.euronews.com/2021/03/16/china-warns-eu-against-confrontational-human-rights-sanctions). Not quite sure if all member states will be willing to harden further the EU stance, especially since the existing sanctions already provide the argument "we have done what we should".
More to lose nothing to gain as Biden ready for any gift to EU for free

Sanctions are looking ever less likely.
"Xinjiang’s exports to the EU boom, despite political concerns over forced labour
* The bloc’s imports of products from the region rise 131 per cent in the first six months, according to an assessment of Chinese customs data
* Some volatility in figures to be expected but debate on labour appears to be having little impact, analysts say"
https://www.scmp.com/news/china/diplomacy/article/3142389/xinjiangs-exports-eu-boom-despite-political-concerns-over

With the Beijing Olympics coming up after Tokyo Olympics, it isn't hard to see international governments imposing fresh sanctions ahead of time, which would also act in spirit of boycott that is evident among some governments but not necessarily in the sports world.

As a defender of HR the EU had a duty to respond to alleged HR violations in Xinjiang, eliciting a response in kind from China and consequently stalling an important trade deal. Neither side benefits from a protracted stand off therefore; there is a very low probability that China will commit further HR violations in Xinjiang and the EU having to respond with sanctions. 0.5%

Will depend on result of German elections.
I think not very likely, but iwll follow consensus for now.
China has been causing ripples on the US financial system with all the Crypto FUDing and we know sometimes that some narratives can serve another purpose.
unless Chinese leadership seriously threatens relations (something I expect them to do exactly once), I cannot imagine any further action beyond words.
It could happen... but I doubt it.

I have revised my prediction likelihood down. I think my previous view was influenced by preference bias but since then I realised that their is little appetite from world leaders for an approach to forcing China in to current world order. Emmanuel Macron has stated that it would be counter productive for western powers "to join together against China" similar sentiment has been raised by Angela Merkel. Hungry which is heading in a more Autocratic direction is unlikely to want to put pressure on China. One person mentioned Germanies reliance on China as a trading partner which I think is an interesting point but Germany may have large enough economy that China will not take the same retaliatory actions as it has against Australia and Canada. They may not want to take the risk though.

Germany will block anything that puts its industry relationship with China at risk, more than 50% of all manufacturing process has China related risks in Germany, so they will hear from Jin if they try something that is less than blocking the EU Human Rights cadre.

Given the note of May 3rd. I suspect that the amount of restrictive measures may be limited to not more than 2, however the qty of individuals/entities may exceed this. 
Motivation behind the possibility of sanctions being imposed is, a growing global culture of sensitivity to human rights abuses. 
A corollary to this is that given the political nature of such events and the strength of the Chinese government, this may prevent many nations, who are reliant on China for trade, to impose restrictive measures beyond the superficial.  However for this question, the superficial restrictions are the ones that I suspect may possibly happen, which would count.
They have done it already and there is lots of time left in the year.  The hurdle has been crossed.. will be easier to continue.

Given that all EU leaders are required to impose sanctions I think even if the motivation was to grow it would be difficult to implement in the time. The EU does hold significant economic power and is not is not as influenced by Chinese economic retaliation as countries like Australia and South Korea. I think there is a push for western democracies to have trade alliances to push back at china and that could be a catalyst to further sanctions. For this reason I do give a decent chance of one sanction but highly doubt anymore will get through.

The US has issued 3 sanctions with a span of 8-9 months in between (Oct 2019, Jul 2020, Mar 2021). The EU has joined only one of these so far (the latest, in Mar 2021). With the only precedent being in 1989, and with EU's trend in consuming more imports from China (19.3% of total imports in the EU in 2020, against the ~17.8% of 2019 and 2018 - source trademap.org) I will stick to simple proportion and apply the historical pattern to the next 8 months.

Wisdom of the crowds as anchor. But making some adjustements. for 3 or more: there is never 0% so it takes one from 2. For the others i believe the probability for 0 is higher due to the fact that i believe that the first will have some effect and that the chinese will at least "pretend" that they do something.

I don't think more sanctions over Xinjiang are likely because 1. the recent sanctions are the first in more than 30 years, 2. the EU is dependent on China for trade, all the more so during the pandemic, and 3. additional sanctions could jeopardize the Comprehensive Agreement on Investment (CAI) that is in the making.

https://www.euronews.com/2021/03/22/eu-foreign-ministers-to-discuss-sanctions-on-china-and-myanmar
Base rate: 2 times in (2021-1989=) 32 years --> 0.0625 times per year
8 months ((2/3) years) between 30 April 2021 and 31 December 2021
0.0625 times/year * (2/3) years = 0.041666... times for the remainder of the year Increase to around 0.40 because of heightened tensions.

EU needs 27 countries to agree more sanctions.
Germany has a big dilemma as a lot of exports go to China - there is a vote on 17 May that might give insight
Lawsuits into companies sourcing cotton from the Uighur region have started and may lead to a ripple effect of more pressure business wise, but these will take time. Relationships are rocky at the moment but it seems like China may want the investment deal to go through (whether it does is on another GJO question).  So could go anywhere at the moment.  I’m inclined to less than more due to investment deal and time needed for things to happen of significant enough impact to trigger sanctions which are quite an extreme form of retaliation. https://thediplomat.com/2021/03/chinas-eu-sanctions-are-the-latest-proof-beijing-doesnt-understand-democracies/
https://www.scmp.com/news/china/diplomacy/article/3131620/china-eu-investment-deal-casts-long-shadow-over-beijings-vague
https://www.politico.eu/article/china-germany-trade-human-rights-angela-merkel-li-keqiang/
https://www.ft.com/content/8ccb0f0d-e64c-4132-b4fb-ab886f4672e9
China has the EU by the throat. The EU has no stomach for confuration.
I guess the EU will hold their feet down as the Economic is strongly dependend on china
